title: Did The Three Point Change The Game ?
text:
The college basketball relationship with the three-point shot has evolved as the line moved farther from the hoop going from 19 feet, to 20, and eventually to 22. With each step back, you’d expect fewer successes, but the data reveals something interesting not only did misses increase, but so did the number of shots MADE.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(hoopR)
library(waffle)
library(gt)

boxscores <- read_csv("ncaa_mens_team_box.csv")

teamseasons <- boxscores |> 
  group_by(season, team_short_display_name) |> 
  summarise(
    total_three_point_attempts = sum(three_point_field_goals_attempted),
    total_three_point_made = sum(three_point_field_goals_made)
  ) |> 
  mutate(season_three_point_pct = (total_three_point_made/total_three_point_attempts)*100) |> 
  mutate(era =
    case_when(
      season == 2003 ~ "19 feet three point line",
      season == 2004 ~ "19 feet three point line",
      season == 2005 ~ "19 feet three point line",
      season == 2006 ~ "19 feet three point line",
      season == 2007 ~ "19 feet three point line",
      season == 2008 ~ "19 feet three point line",
      season == 2009 ~ "20 feet three point line",
      season == 2010 ~ "20 feet three point line",
      season == 2011 ~ "20 feet three point line",
      season == 2012 ~ "20 feet three point line",
      season == 2013 ~ "20 feet three point line",
      season == 2014 ~ "20 feet three point line",
      season == 2015 ~ "20 feet three point line",
      season == 2016 ~ "20 feet three point line",
      season == 2017 ~ "20 feet three point line",
      season == 2018 ~ "20 feet three point line",
      season == 2019 ~ "20 feet three point line",
      season == 2020 ~ "22 feet three point line",
      season == 2021 ~ "22 feet three point line",
      season == 2022 ~ "22 feet three point line",
      season == 2023 ~ "22 feet three point line",
      season == 2024 ~ "22 feet three point line",
      season == 2025 ~ "22 feet three point line",
    ))


eras <- teamseasons |>
group_by(era) |>
  summarise(
    avg_three_point_attempt= mean(total_three_point_attempts),
    avg_three_point_made= mean(total_three_point_made)
    ) |>
  mutate(avg_three_point_misses=avg_three_point_attempt-avg_three_point_made)

era19 <- c("Made"=123.5469, "Misses"=231.0066)
era20 <- c("Made"=127.4603, "Misses"=242.8541)
era22 <- c("Made"=130.2392, "Misses"=256.3559)

iron(
waffle(
        era19/10, 
        rows = 3, 
        colors = c("green", "red")
) +
  labs(
    x = "19-foot three point line",
    title="The More The Merrier", 
    subtitle="More distance leads to more misses — but made shots increase too"
    ) + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10),
    axis.title.y = element_blank()
  ),
waffle(
        era20/10, 
        rows = 3, 
        colors = c("green", "red") 
) + 
  labs(
    x= "20-foot three point line"
  ),
waffle(
        era22/10, 
        rows = 3, 
        colors = c("green", "red")
) +
  labs(
    x= "22-foot three point line",
    caption="Source: NCAA | Graphic by Ashriel Dixon"
  )
)









The different era of the three-point line, comparing average attempts, makes, and misses. But the real conflict comes in the making. On the modern 22-foot era a nod to how far the game has come. The designs shows a simple truth even as the shots get tougher, players keep pushing the limits which is crazy.


Code
eras |> 
   gt() |> 
  cols_label(
    era = "Era",
    avg_three_point_attempt = "Avg. Three Point Attempts",
    avg_three_point_made = "Avg. Three Point Makes",
    avg_three_point_misses = "Avg. Three Point Misses"
  ) |>
  tab_header(
    title = "Deeper Is Better",
    subtitle = "Keep Shooting."
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  ) |>
  tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("**By:** Ashriel Dixon  |  **Source:** NCAA")
  ) |>
  tab_style(
     locations = cells_column_labels(columns = everything()),
     style = list(
       cell_borders(sides = "bottom", weight = px(3)),
       cell_text(weight = "bold", size=12)
     )
   ) |>
  opt_row_striping() |>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "orange"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = era == "22 feet three point line")
  )








Deeper Is Better


Keep Shooting.


Era
Avg. Three Point Attempts
Avg. Three Point Makes
Avg. Three Point Misses




19 feet three point line
354.5536
123.5469
231.0066


20 feet three point line
370.3144
127.4603
242.8541


22 feet three point line
386.5951
130.2392
256.3559



By: Ashriel Dixon | Source: NCAA








The trigger-happy teams in college basketball history… The top 20 ranked squads who let it fly from deep more than anyone else. These high-volume shooters from the eras are just mind blowing. 19-foot , 20-foot, and the 22-foot line era seem backwards. The title says it all “The 19 Foot Line Has Left the Chat” a witty nod to how the top shooters now mostly come from eras where the line was pushed back. And yet, even with more distance, teams continue to chuck away, showing just how central the three-point shot has become. All Thanks To STEPHEN CURRY himself!


Code
topchuckers <- teamseasons |> 
  ungroup() |> 
  top_n(20, wt=total_three_point_attempts) |> 
  mutate(team_season = paste(team_short_display_name, season))

ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=topchuckers, aes(x=reorder(team_season, total_three_point_attempts), weight=total_three_point_attempts, fill=era)) + 
  coord_flip() + 
  scale_fill_manual(values=c("green", "yellow", "blue")) + 
  labs(
    x="", 
    y="Three point attempts", 
    title="The 19 Foot Line Has Left The Chat", 
    subtitle="Moving Back", 
    caption="Source: NCAA | By Ashriel Dixon"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    )

title: Is Ashton Jeanty The Bet Runningback Since 2016 ?
text:
Boise State running back Ashton Jeanty delivered a remarkable performance, leading the nation with 2,601 rushing yards which separated him from all the other going back to 2016. Jeanty didn’t just have a good season he fell short 28 yards of Barry Sanders ALL TIME rushing yards in a season putting him in the penultimate position.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(ggalt)
library(ggtext)
library(rvest)
library(gt)

rushing24url <- "https://cfbstats.com/2024/leader/national/player/split01/category01/sort01.html"

rushing24list <- rushing24url |> 
  read_html() |> 
  html_elements(xpath = '//*[@id="content"]/div[2]/table') |> 
  html_table()

rushing24 <- rushing24list[[1]] |> 
  rename(Rank = 1) |> 
  mutate(Season = 2024)

rushing23url <- "https://cfbstats.com/2023/leader/national/player/split01/category01/sort01.html"

rushing23list <- rushing23url |> 
  read_html() |> 
  html_elements(xpath = '//*[@id="content"]/div[2]/table') |> 
  html_table()

rushing23 <- rushing23list[[1]] |> 
  rename(Rank = 1) |> 
  mutate(Season = 2023)

rushing22url <- "https://cfbstats.com/2022/leader/national/player/split01/category01/sort01.html"

rushing22list <- rushing22url |> 
  read_html() |> 
  html_elements(xpath = '//*[@id="content"]/div[2]/table') |> 
  html_table()

rushing22 <- rushing22list[[1]] |> 
  rename(Rank = 1) |> 
  mutate(Season = 2022)

rushing21url <- "https://cfbstats.com/2021/leader/national/player/split01/category01/sort01.html"

rushing21list <- rushing21url |> 
  read_html() |> 
  html_elements(xpath = '//*[@id="content"]/div[2]/table') |> 
  html_table()

rushing21 <- rushing21list[[1]] |> 
  rename(Rank = 1) |> 
  mutate(Season = 2021)

rushing20url <- "https://cfbstats.com/2020/leader/national/player/split01/category01/sort01.html"

rushing20list <- rushing20url |> 
  read_html() |> 
  html_elements(xpath = '//*[@id="content"]/div[2]/table') |> 
  html_table()

rushing20 <- rushing20list[[1]] |> 
  rename(Rank = 1) |> 
  mutate(Season = 2020)

rushing19url <- "https://cfbstats.com/2019/leader/national/player/split01/category01/sort01.html"

rushing19list <- rushing19url |> 
  read_html() |> 
  html_elements(xpath = '//*[@id="content"]/div[2]/table') |> 
  html_table()

rushing19 <- rushing19list[[1]] |> 
  rename(Rank = 1) |> 
  mutate(Season = 2019)

rushing18url <- "https://cfbstats.com/2018/leader/national/player/split01/category01/sort01.html"

rushing18list <- rushing18url |> 
  read_html() |> 
  html_elements(xpath = '//*[@id="content"]/div[2]/table') |> 
  html_table()

rushing18 <- rushing18list[[1]] |> 
  rename(Rank = 1) |> 
  mutate(Season = 2018)

rushing17url <- "https://cfbstats.com/2017/leader/national/player/split01/category01/sort01.html"

rushing17list <- rushing17url |> 
  read_html() |> 
  html_elements(xpath = '//*[@id="content"]/div[2]/table') |> 
  html_table()

rushing17 <- rushing17list[[1]] |> 
  rename(Rank = 1) |> 
  mutate(Season = 2017)

rushing16url <- "https://cfbstats.com/2016/leader/national/player/split01/category01/sort01.html"

rushing16list <- rushing16url |> 
  read_html() |> 
  html_elements(xpath = '//*[@id="content"]/div[2]/table') |> 
  html_table()

rushing16 <- rushing16list[[1]] |> 
  rename(Rank = 1) |> 
  mutate(Season = 2016)

rushing <- bind_rows(rushing16, rushing17, rushing18, rushing19, rushing20, rushing21, rushing21, rushing22, rushing23,rushing24) |> 
  mutate(PlayerSeason = paste(Name, Season))


aj <- rushing |> filter(Name == "Ashton Jeanty")

ggplot() + 
  geom_point(data=rushing, aes(x=Att, y=Yards), color="grey") + 
  geom_point(data=aj, aes(x=Att, y=Yards), color="#0033A0") + 
labs(
    x="Yards", 
    y="Rushing Yards", 
    title="Jeanty has the biggest outbreak season since 2016", 
    subtitle="AJ historic season led him to being number 2 all time in rushing yards.", 
    caption="Source: CFB | By Ashriel Dixon"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(plot.title.position = "plot" ,
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
    ) 









Ashtons historic performance by scoring 29 rushing touchdowns, which set a new single season record for the program. His scoring skill set was evident, as he tied the school and Mountain West records with six rushing touchdowns in the season opener against Georgia Southern.


Code
rushing |> 
  arrange(desc(TD)) |> 
  top_n(10, wt=TD) |> 
  select(Name, Team, Pos, Yr, TD, Season) |> 
  gt() |> 
  cols_label(
    TD = "TouchDowns Scored"
  ) |>
  tab_header(
    title = "Number 3 in Tocuhdowns Since 2016?",
    subtitle = "Jeanty was projeted to score 2 or more TD's in every game."
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  ) |>
  tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("**By:** Ashriel Dixon |  **Source:** CFB:")
  ) |>
  tab_style(
     locations = cells_column_labels(columns = everything()),
     style = list(
       cell_borders(sides = "bottom", weight = px(3)),
       cell_text(weight = "bold", size=12)
     )
   ) |>
  opt_row_striping() |> 
  opt_table_lines("none") |>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "#0033A0"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
        rows = Name == "Ashton Jeanty")
  )








Number 3 in Tocuhdowns Since 2016?


Jeanty was projeted to score 2 or more TD's in every game.

By: Ashriel Dixon | Source: CFB:








AJ took care of business, averaging about 26.7 carries per game over 14 games. His total of 374 carries led the nation and marked one of the heaviest single seasons. Despite the high volume, he maintained an impressive 7.0 yards per carry, showing his efficiency and resilience throughout the season.


Code
rushingtop10 <- rushing |> 
  top_n(10, wt=`Yards/G`) 

jeanty <- rushingtop10 |> filter(Name=="Ashton Jeanty")

ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=rushingtop10, aes(x=reorder(PlayerSeason, `Att/G`), weight=`Att/G`),fill="grey") +
  
geom_bar(data=jeanty, aes(x=reorder(PlayerSeason, `Att/G`), weight=`Att/G`),fill="#0033A0") +
  coord_flip() +
labs(
    x="", 
    y=" AVG Rushing Attempts per game ", 
    title="26 carries a game with his rushing avg...GOAT ", 
    subtitle=" I wouldn't keep the ball out his hands either", 
    caption="Source: CFB | By Ashriel Dixon"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(plot.title.position = "plot" ,
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
    )
